article_title: Health Costs Hinge on Supreme Court Ruling
article_text:
After the Affordable Care Act kicked in, Michael Kole’s monthly health-insurance premium to cover himself and his family grew to $848 from $513. Like others, he wasn’t happy about it. “It’s taking a lot out of pocket,” he said.

The 52-year-old sales and marketing entrepreneur is one of millions of Americans who earn too much to qualify for government subsidies on policies purchased through the federal insurance exchange. To save...

article_metadata.article.origheadline: Health Costs Hinge on Supreme Court Ruling

article_summary:
The 52-year-old sales and marketing entrepreneur is one of millions of Americans who earn too much to qualify for government subsidies on policies purchased through the federal insurance exchange.
After the Affordable Care Act kicked in, Michael Kole’s monthly health-insurance premium to cover himself and his family grew to $848 from $513.
“It’s taking a lot out of pocket,” he said.
Like others, he wasn’t happy about it.
